title: Creating Descriptive Table 1 Summaries with svyTable1
text: svytable1() function defaults mode = "mixed". approach considered best practice high-quality survey research promotes transparency. present table mixed mode, two types information shown categorical variables: Unweighted N: actual number survey respondents category. indicates precision (Seidenberg, Moser, West 2023). Weighted Percentage: proportion target population estimated fall category, accounting survey design (Health Statistics (US) 1994). structure prevents common reporting problems showing weighted counts (represent real sample sizes) hiding sparse categories contribute instability. continuous variables, function reports weighted means, standard errors, confidence intervals. also offers optional reliability checks derived National Center Health Statistics (NCHS) guidance, including standard error relative standard error thresholds.

title: Creating Descriptive Table 1 Summaries with svyTable1
text: examples use data NHANES raw dataset demonstrate prepare survey design generate descriptive tables. code illustrates incomplete data situations complete case summaries.

title: Creating Descriptive Table 1 Summaries with svyTable1
code: library(svyTable1) library(survey) library(dplyr) library(NHANES) library(knitr) library(tidyr) data(NHANESraw)  nhanes_adults_with_na <- NHANESraw %>%   dplyr::filter(Age >= 20) %>%   mutate(     ObeseStatus = factor(       ifelse(BMI >= 30, "Obese", "Not Obese"),       levels = c("Not Obese", "Obese")     )   )  adult_design_with_na <- svydesign(   id = ~SDMVPSU,   strata = ~SDMVSTRA,   weights = ~WTMEC2YR,   nest = TRUE,   data = nhanes_adults_with_na )

what: Example A: Handling Variables with Missing Data
title: Creating Descriptive Table 1 Summaries with svyTable1
text: Variables large health surveys often contain missing values. svytable1() automatically identifies missingness calculates unweighted Ns reflect real denominators. Weighted percentages based cases observed data, consistent standard survey practice. Table 1: Summarizing Variables Missing Data
code: vars_with_missing <- c(   "Age", "Gender", "Race1", "Education", "HHIncome",   "TotChol", "SleepHrsNight", "SmokeNow" )  table_with_missing <- svytable1(   design = adult_design_with_na,   strata_var = "ObeseStatus",   table_vars = vars_with_missing )  knitr::kable(   table_with_missing,   caption = "Table 1: Summarizing Variables with Missing Data" )

previous_headings: Example: Using NHANES Data (2009–2012) > 2. Generating Tables
title: Creating Descriptive Table 1 Summaries with svyTable1
text: prefer restrict analysis respondents complete data chosen set variables, can construct complete analytic dataset supply new svydesign object. function calculates summary statistics without missing categories. Table 2: Summarizing Variables Missing Data
code: vars_for_complete_table <- c(   "Age", "Gender", "Race1", "BPSysAve", "Pulse", "BMI" )  nhanes_adults_complete <- nhanes_adults_with_na %>%   drop_na(all_of(vars_for_complete_table))  adult_design_complete <- svydesign(   id = ~SDMVPSU,   strata = ~SDMVSTRA,   weights = ~WTMEC2YR,   nest = TRUE,   data = nhanes_adults_complete )  table_without_missing <- svytable1(   design = adult_design_complete,   strata_var = "ObeseStatus",   table_vars = c("Age", "Gender", "Race1", "BPSysAve", "Pulse") )  knitr::kable(   table_without_missing,   caption = "Table 2: Summarizing Variables with No Missing Data" )

what: 3. Checking Estimate Reliability for Proportions (NCHS Standards)
title: Creating Descriptive Table 1 Summaries with svyTable1
text: Federal statistical agencies discourage reporting proportions unstable based small samples. request reliability_checks = TRUE, svytable1() returns: formatted table suppressed estimates. companion metrics table showing estimates failed reliability standards. checks follow NCHS guidance evaluation proportions complex surveys. Estimates relative standard error values recommended thresholds marked suppressed. Table 3: Table NCHS Reliability Checks Applied Reliability Metrics Suppressed Estimates
code: results_list <- svytable1(   design = adult_design_with_na,   strata_var = "ObeseStatus",   table_vars = vars_with_missing,   reliability_checks = TRUE,   return_metrics = TRUE )  knitr::kable(   results_list$formatted_table,   caption = "Table 3: Table with NCHS Reliability Checks Applied" ) knitr::kable(   results_list$reliability_metrics[     results_list$reliability_metrics$suppressed == TRUE, ],   caption = "Reliability Metrics for Suppressed Estimates" )

what: 4. Checking Estimate Reliability for Means (NCHS Standards)
title: Creating Descriptive Table 1 Summaries with svyTable1
text: numeric variables, svytable1() performs additional check: fail_rse_30: Flags means whose relative standard error (RSE) least 30 percent. RSE calculated : RSE ≥ 30 percent indicates unreliable estimate based NCHS guidance.
code: RSE = (Standard Error / Estimate) * 100

title: Diagnosing Survey Regression Models with svyTable1
text: examples use complete-case NHANES data adults aged 20 years older. survey-weighted logistic regression model fitted predict obesity. model used throughout vignette illustrate diagnostic function.
code: library(svyTable1) library(survey) library(dplyr) library(NHANES) library(knitr) library(tidyr) library(ggplot2) data(NHANESraw)  nhanes_adults_with_na <- NHANESraw %>%   filter(Age >= 20) %>%   mutate(     ObeseStatus = factor(       ifelse(BMI >= 30, "Obese", "Not Obese"),       levels = c("Not Obese", "Obese")     )   )  vars_for_complete_table <- c(   "Age", "Gender", "Race1", "BPSysAve",   "Pulse", "BMI", "ObeseStatus" )  nhanes_adults_complete <- nhanes_adults_with_na %>%   drop_na(all_of(vars_for_complete_table))  adult_design_complete <- svydesign(   id = ~SDMVPSU,   strata = ~SDMVSTRA,   weights = ~WTMEC2YR,   nest = TRUE,   data = nhanes_adults_complete )  fit_obesity <- svyglm(   ObeseStatus ~ Age + Gender + Race1,   design = adult_design_complete,   family = quasibinomial() )

title: Diagnosing Survey Regression Models with svyTable1
text: svydiag() produces diagnostics regression coefficients, including p-values, precision measures, relative standard errors. Reliability Diagnostics NHANES Obesity Model
code: diagnostics_table <- svydiag(fit_obesity)  knitr::kable(   diagnostics_table,   caption = "Reliability Diagnostics for NHANES Obesity Model",   digits = 3 )

title: Diagnosing Survey Regression Models with svyTable1
text: Estimate: Coefficient log-odds scale. p.value, is_significant: Indicate statistical significance. CI_Width: Reflects precision estimate. RSE_percent, is_rse_high: Highlight limitations RSE estimates near zero.

title: Diagnosing Survey Regression Models with svyTable1
text: svygof() implements Archer Lemeshow goodness fit procedure complex survey logistic regression (Archer Lemeshow 2006). test adapts Hosmer Lemeshow approach designs weights, strata, clustering. function groups respondents predicted risk compares observed expected outcomes incorporating survey weights. small p-value provides evidence predicted risks diverge observed risks one groups. test helps identify lack fit may result omitted interactions nonlinearities model. Archer-Lemeshow Goodness--Fit Test Obesity Model significant p-value indicates poor model fit across predicted risk groups.
code: gof_results <- svygof(fit_obesity, adult_design_complete)  knitr::kable(   gof_results,   caption = "Archer-Lemeshow Goodness-of-Fit Test for Obesity Model" )

title: Diagnosing Survey Regression Models with svyTable1
text: svyAUC() estimates area ROC curve using replicate-weight designs. produces AUC estimate confidence interval appropriately reflect survey sampling. function also returns data constructing ROC curves. plot ROC curve, along AUC estimate, demonstrates well model discriminates obese non-obese respondents. value close 0.5 indicates little discriminatory value, higher values indicate stronger predictive performance.  Design-Correct AUC Obesity Model
code: rep_design <- as.svrepdesign(adult_design_complete)  fit_obesity_rep <- svyglm(   ObeseStatus ~ Age + Gender + Race1,   design = rep_design,   family = quasibinomial() )  auc_results_list <- svyAUC(fit_obesity_rep, rep_design, plot = TRUE) knitr::kable(   auc_results_list$summary,   caption = "Design-Correct AUC for Obesity Model" ) ggplot(auc_results_list$roc_data, aes(x = FPR, y = TPR)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1) +  # Changed 'size' to 'linewidth'   geom_abline(linetype = "dashed") +   labs(     title = "Survey-Weighted ROC Curve",     subtitle = paste0("AUC = ", round(auc_results_list$summary$AUC, 3)),     x = "1 - Specificity (FPR)",     y = "Sensitivity (TPR)"   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: Analyzing Interaction Effects with svyTable1
text: svyTable1 package includes several functions help analyze present interaction effects two categorical variables survey-weighted regression models (svyglm svycoxph). functions facilitate demonstrating equivalence different modeling approaches calculating measures additive interaction.

what: Example: Interaction between Race and Obesity on Hypertension (NHANES)
title: Analyzing Interaction Effects with svyTable1
text: two categorical variables, svyTable1 provides functions summarize joint, simple, additive interaction effects survey-weighted logistic Cox models. summaries help demonstrate connection saturated interaction model equivalent joint-indicator model.

title: Analyzing Interaction Effects with svyTable1
text: example uses NHANES data examine whether association obesity hypertension differs race. survey-weighted logistic model interaction term fitted, matched joint-indicator model created demonstrate equivalence.
code: library(svyTable1) library(survey) library(dplyr) library(NHANES) library(knitr) library(tidyr) library(emmeans) library(ggplot2) data(NHANESraw)  vars_needed <- c("Age", "Race1", "BPSysAve", "BMI", "ObeseStatus", "Hypertension_130",                  "SDMVPSU", "SDMVSTRA", "WTMEC2YR")  nhanes_adults_processed <- NHANESraw %>%   filter(Age >= 20) %>%   mutate(     ObeseStatus = factor(ifelse(BMI >= 30, "Obese", "Not Obese"),                          levels = c("Not Obese", "Obese")),     Hypertension_130 = factor(ifelse(BPSysAve >= 130, "Yes", "No"),                               levels = c("No", "Yes")),     Race1 = relevel(as.factor(Race1), ref = "White")   ) %>%   select(all_of(vars_needed)) %>%   drop_na()  adult_design_binary <- svydesign(   id = ~SDMVPSU,   strata = ~SDMVSTRA,   weights = ~WTMEC2YR,   nest = TRUE,   data = nhanes_adults_processed )  interaction_model_logit <- svyglm(   Hypertension_130 ~ Race1 * ObeseStatus + Age,   design = adult_design_binary,   family = quasibinomial() )  adult_design_binary <- update(adult_design_binary,   Race1_ObeseStatus = interaction(Race1, ObeseStatus, sep = "_", drop = TRUE) )  adult_design_binary <- update(adult_design_binary,   Race1_ObeseStatus = relevel(Race1_ObeseStatus, ref = "White_Not Obese") )  joint_model_logit <- svyglm(   Hypertension_130 ~ Race1_ObeseStatus + Age,   design = adult_design_binary,   family = quasibinomial() )  f1_levels <- levels(adult_design_binary$variables$Race1) f2_levels <- levels(adult_design_binary$variables$ObeseStatus)

title: Analyzing Interaction Effects with svyTable1
text: addintlist() computes standard measures additive interaction. include: RERI (relative excess risk due interaction) AP (attributable proportion due interaction) S (synergy index) measures quantify departure additivity ratio scale help assess whether joint effect two exposures exceeds expected independent effects. Additive Interaction Measures (RERI, AP, S) Race x Obesity Hypertension
code: all_interactions_table <- addintlist(   model = interaction_model_logit,   factor1_name = "Race1",   factor2_name = "ObeseStatus",   measures = "all",   digits = 3 ) #> Calculating for: Race1_Black_vs_ObeseStatus_Obese #> Calculating for: Race1_Hispanic_vs_ObeseStatus_Obese #> Calculating for: Race1_Mexican_vs_ObeseStatus_Obese #> Calculating for: Race1_Other_vs_ObeseStatus_Obese  knitr::kable(all_interactions_table,   caption = "Additive Interaction Measures (RERI, AP, S) for Race x Obesity on Hypertension",   digits = 3)

title: Analyzing Interaction Effects with svyTable1
text: jointeffects() estimates combined effect combination two categorical variables. function reports effects either ratio scale log scale useful reporting full pattern interaction across subgroups. Joint Effects (Scale) Estimated Interaction Model Joint Effects (Log-Scale) Estimated Interaction Model
code: joint_effects_ratio <- jointeffects(   interaction_model = interaction_model_logit,   factor1_name = "Race1",   factor2_name = "ObeseStatus",   scale = "ratio",   digits = 2)  knitr::kable(joint_effects_ratio,   caption = "Joint Effects (OR Scale) Estimated from Interaction Model",   digits = 2) joint_effects_log <- jointeffects(   interaction_model = interaction_model_logit,   factor1_name = "Race1",   factor2_name = "ObeseStatus",   scale = "log",   digits = 3)  knitr::kable(joint_effects_log,   caption = "Joint Effects (Log-OR Scale) Estimated from Interaction Model",   digits = 3)

title: Analyzing Interaction Effects with svyTable1
text: inteffects() provides stratum-specific effects. example, reports effect obesity within racial group effect race within obesity category. helps identify group-specific comparisons drive interaction. Simple Effects (Scale) Estimated Joint Model Simple Effects (Log-Scale) Estimated Joint Model
code: simple_effects_ratio <- inteffects(   joint_model = joint_model_logit,   joint_var_name = "Race1_ObeseStatus",   factor1_name = "Race1",   factor2_name = "ObeseStatus",   factor1_levels = f1_levels,   factor2_levels = f2_levels,   level_separator = "_",   scale = "ratio",   digits = 2)  knitr::kable(simple_effects_ratio,   caption = "Simple Effects (OR Scale) Estimated from Joint Model",   digits = 2) simple_effects_log <- inteffects(   joint_model = joint_model_logit,   joint_var_name = "Race1_ObeseStatus",   factor1_name = "Race1",   factor2_name = "ObeseStatus",   factor1_levels = f1_levels,   factor2_levels = f2_levels,   level_separator = "_",   scale = "log",   digits = 3)  knitr::kable(simple_effects_log,   caption = "Simple Effects (Log-OR Scale) Estimated from Joint Model",   digits = 3)

title: Analyzing Interaction Effects with svyTable1
text: plotint() produces plots predicted outcomes across values continuous predictor selected levels continuous categorical moderator. function uses survey-weighted marginal estimates, supports model data driven moderator scales, returns data plot object. approach helpful evaluating interactions continuous variables, reporting numerical contrasts often impractical.
code: data("NHANESraw") nhanes_clean <- NHANESraw %>%   filter(Age >= 20) %>%   mutate(     Gender = factor(Gender),     Race1 = factor(Race1)   ) %>%   select(     BPSysAve, Age, BMI, Gender, Race1,     SDMVPSU, SDMVSTRA, WTMEC2YR   ) %>%   na.omit()  design_nhanes <- svydesign(   id = ~SDMVPSU,   strata = ~SDMVSTRA,   weights = ~WTMEC2YR,   nest = TRUE,   data = nhanes_clean )  model_bp_interaction <- svyglm(   BPSysAve ~ Age * BMI + Gender + Race1,   design = design_nhanes,   family = gaussian(link = "log") )  plot_data_list <- plotint(   model = model_bp_interaction,   effect = "Age",   moderator = "BMI",   data = nhanes_clean,   mod_scale = "quantile",   type = "response",   show_ci = TRUE,   bw = FALSE,   pval_position = "bottom.right",   xlab = "Age (Years)",   ylab = "Predicted Geometric Mean SBP (mmHg)",   legend_title = "BMI (Percentiles)" ) head(plot_data_list$plot_data) #>  BMI                    Age  y_value        SE df     ymin     ymax tvar  #>  10th %ile (21.5)  20.00000 106.7788 0.5574646 25 105.6368 107.9331 21.5  #>  50th %ile (27.9)  20.00000 110.2419 0.4104105 25 109.3999 111.0904 27.9  #>  90th %ile (37.77) 20.00000 115.8042 0.6207428 25 114.5327 117.0897 37.77 #>  10th %ile (21.5)  20.60606 107.0466 0.5529424 25 105.9138 108.1915 21.5  #>  50th %ile (27.9)  20.60606 110.4755 0.4086058 25 109.6371 111.3202 27.9  #>  90th %ile (37.77) 20.60606 115.9800 0.6154211 25 114.7194 117.2545 37.77 #>      xvar #>  20.00000 #>  20.00000 #>  20.00000 #>  20.60606 #>  20.60606 #>  20.60606 #>  #> Results are averaged over the levels of: Gender, Race1  #> Confidence level used: 0.95  #> Intervals are back-transformed from the log scale

title: Survival Analysis with svyTable1
text: svykmplot() produces Kaplan–Meier survival estimates correctly incorporate survey weights, strata, clusters. function returns plot number--risk table. plot supports automatic custom colors, p-value display, censoring indicators. example uses NHANES linked mortality file compare survival across levels caffeine consumption among women. number--risk table printed beneath plot, required common reporting guidelines.
code: library(svyTable1) library(survey) library(knitr) library(survival) library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) library(mitools) library(mice) data(nhanes_mortality)  analytic_design <- svydesign(   strata = ~strata,   id = ~psu,   weights = ~survey_weight,   data = nhanes_mortality,   nest = TRUE )  design_female <- subset(analytic_design, sex == "Female")  km_formula <- Surv(stime, status) ~ caff  distinct_palette <- c("#377EB8", "#FF7F00", "#4DAF4A", "#E41A1C")  km_results_female <- svykmplot(   formula = km_formula,   design = design_female,   legend_title = "Caffeine Consumption",   time_unit = "days",   time_breaks = seq(0, 240, by = 60),   palette = distinct_palette,   show_pval = TRUE,   show_censor_marks = TRUE ) km_results_female$plot #> Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_step()`). #> Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_ribbon()`). #> Warning: Removed 38 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_point()`). knitr::kable(   km_results_female$table,   caption = "Number at Risk for Female Mortality Plot" )

what: 2. Ad hoc solutions for testing Proportional Hazards
title: Survival Analysis with svyTable1
text: R functions, svycoxph_CE (single survey designs) svycoxph_CE_mi (multiply imputed survey designs), ad hoc solutions testing Proportional Hazards (PH) assumption complex survey data analysis environment.

previous_headings: 2. Ad hoc solutions for testing Proportional Hazards
title: Survival Analysis with svyTable1
text: functions implement core strategy assessing PH assumption, violated effect covariate changes time (.e., β(t)≠β\beta(t) \neq \beta). transform proportional hazards model (second equation ) time-dependent coefficient model using step-function approach. fundamental Cox models : Proportional Hazards (PH):λ(t)=λ0(t)eβX\lambda(t) = \lambda_{0}(t) e^{\beta X} Time-Dependent Coefficient:λ(t)=λ0(t)eβ(t)X\lambda(t) = \lambda_{0}(t) e^{\beta(t)X} step-function approach works : Defining Time Intervals: total follow-time split nn distinct intervals (example, 5 quantiles event times). Splitting Data: input dataset expanded start-stop format using survival::survSplit(). single subject’s follow-broken multiple rows, one time interval contribute . Fitting Interval-Specific Models: separate Cox model fitted time interval. achieved including term asvar_to_test:strata(tgroup) subsetting data interval variable (tgroup) usingSurv(tstart, time, status) ~ ... model formula. Multiple Imputation Support: svycoxph_CE_mi, interval model pooled across multiple imputations using mitools::pool(). Extracting Plotting Coefficients: functions extract coefficient (β̂\hat{\beta}) standard error variable tested across intervals, plot time. Interpretation true effect constant (PH holds), plotted coefficients cluster around overall constant-effect estimate, confidence intervals overlapping overall mean null-effect line. clear time trend step-function coefficients suggests PH violation.

previous_headings: 2. Ad hoc solutions for testing Proportional Hazards
what: Why These are Ad Hoc Solutions, and Why the Specialized Functions are Necessary
title: Survival Analysis with svyTable1
text: svycoxph_CE svycoxph_CE.mi functions “ad hoc” solutions; purpose-built solve gap R’s survival analysis ecosystem. Standard methods testing proportional hazards assumption fail faced combined complexity survey design, multiple imputation, time-varying coefficients. function correct solution successfully navigates three distinct incompatibilities standard packages: Incompatibility cox.zph() svycoxph standard function cox.zph() (based Schoenfeld residuals) used svycoxph objects. Using non-survey coxph model, even weights() term, ignores clusters strata, leading incorrect standard errors invalid p-values. Potential Solution: svycoxph_CE functions use svycoxph every calculation, ensuring survey design’s variance estimation correctly applied steps. Incompatibility tt() svycoxph “correct” way model continuously time-varying coefficient (e.g., β(t)=+blog(t)\beta(t) = + b \log(t)) coxph model use tt() (time-transform) argument. Problem: tt() argument implemented survey::svycoxph function. researcher using survey data therefore technically blocked using method. Potential Solution: step-function approach robust, non-parametric alternative. fitting separate models discrete time intervals, makes assumptions shape effect time fully compatible svycoxph. Incompatibility cox.zph() Multiple Imputation Standard diagnostics like cox.zph() designed “pooled” across multiply-imputed datasets. researcher might incorrectly run test just one imputed dataset , worse, stacked (long-format) data, invalid. Potential Solution: svycoxph_CE.mi function correctly handles multiple imputation fitting step-function model separately imputed dataset pooling results using Rubin’s Rules (mitools::pool()). produces single, valid estimate confidence interval coefficient time interval. Avoiding “Obvious Incorrect” log(t) Trap common mistake (Therneau, Crowson, Atkinson 2017) test PH assumption adding simple interaction like covariate:log(time) formula. Problem: statistically invalid, introduces circular logic. uses subject’s final follow-time (part outcome) predictor hazard earlier time points . Potential Solution: survSplit method avoids partitioning data (start, stop] intervals. model given interval t uses data subjects still risk, correctly adhering principles survival analysis.

title: Survival Analysis with svyTable1
text: Multiple Imputation Case (svycoxph_CE_mi)
code: data(nhanes_mortality)  analytic_design <- svydesign(   strata = ~strata,   id = ~psu,   weights = ~survey_weight,   data = nhanes_mortality,   nest = TRUE )  data_full_clean <- analytic_design$variables %>%   dplyr::filter(stime > 0) %>%   mutate(     caff_bin = factor(       ifelse(caff == "No consumption", "No", "Yes"),       levels = c("No", "Yes")     )   )  analytic_design_final <- svydesign(   strata = ~strata,   id = ~psu,   weights = ~survey_weight,   data = data_full_clean,   nest = TRUE )  my_formula <- "caff_bin + age" my_var <- "age"  svycoxph_CE(   formula_rhs = my_formula,   design = analytic_design_final,   var_to_test = my_var,   time_var = "stime",   status_var = "status",   n_intervals = 5,   verbose = TRUE,   print_main_model = TRUE,   print_split_summary = TRUE ) #> [1] "--- Fitting Main (Constant Effect) Model ---" #> Stratified 1 - level Cluster Sampling design (with replacement) #> With (180) clusters. #> svydesign(strata = replacement) #> With (139) clusters. #> subset(split_design, split_design$variables$tgroup == i) #> [1] "--- Summary of Time-Interval Models ---" #>  #>  #> |Time.Interval |Variable    |    HR| data(nhanes_mortality)  analytic_design <- svydesign(   strata = ~strata,   id = ~psu,   weights = ~survey_weight,   data = nhanes_mortality,   nest = TRUE )  set.seed(123) data_with_miss <- analytic_design$variables %>%   dplyr::filter(stime > 0) %>%   mutate(     caff_bin = factor(       ifelse(caff == "No consumption", "No", "Yes"),       levels = c("No", "Yes")     ),     age = ifelse(runif(n()) < 0.10, NA, age),     bmi_cat = factor(ifelse(age > 50 & runif(n()) < 0.15, NA, as.character(bmi.cat)))   )  print(mice::md.pattern(data_with_miss[, c("age", "bmi_cat", "caff_bin", "stime", "status")], plot = FALSE)) #>      caff_bin stime status age bmi_cat     #> 2994        1     1      1   1       1   0 #> 401         1     1      1   1       0   1 #> 343         1     1      1   0       1   1 #> 42          1     1      1   0       0   2 #>             0     0      0 385     443 828  data_with_miss$nelson_aalen <- nelsonaalen(   data_with_miss,   time = stime,   status = status )  M_IMPUTATIONS <- 2 MAX_ITERATIONS <- 2  pred_matrix <- make.predictorMatrix(data_with_miss) vars_to_keep_as_is <- c("id", "survey.weight", "psu", "strata",                         "stime", "status", "nelson_aalen", "caff_bin", "sex")  pred_matrix[, vars_to_keep_as_is] <- 0 pred_matrix[vars_to_keep_as_is, ] <- 0  imputed_data <- mice(   data_with_miss,   m = M_IMPUTATIONS,   maxit = MAX_ITERATIONS,   predictorMatrix = pred_matrix,   method = "pmm",   seed = 123,   printFlag = FALSE ) #> Warning: Number of logged events: 4  impdata_long <- mice::complete(imputed_data, "long", include = FALSE)  allImputations_main <- imputationList(split(impdata_long, impdata_long$.imp)) design_main <- svydesign(   strata = ~strata,   id = ~psu,   weights = ~survey_weight,   data = allImputations_main,   nest = TRUE )  my_formula <- "caff_bin + sex + age + bmi_cat" main_formula <- as.formula(paste0("Surv(stime, status) ~ ", my_formula))  main_fit_list <- with(design_main, svycoxph(main_formula)) main_fit_pooled <- pool(main_fit_list) #> Stratified 1 - level Cluster Sampling design (with replacement) #> With (180) clusters. #> svydesign(ids = ids, probs = probs, strata = strata, variables = variables,  #>     fpc = fpc, nest = nest, check.strata = check.strata, weights = weights,  #>     data = d, pps = pps, calibrate.formula = calibrate.formula,  #>     ...) #> Stratified 1 - level Cluster Sampling design (with replacement) #> With (180) clusters. #> svydesign(ids = ids, probs = probs, strata = strata, variables = variables,  #>     fpc = fpc, nest = nest, check.strata = check.strata, weights = weights,  #>     data = d, pps = pps, calibrate.formula = calibrate.formula,  #>     ...) #> Stratified 1 - level Cluster Sampling design (with replacement) #> With (180) clusters. #> svydesign(ids = ids, probs = probs, strata = strata, variables = variables,  #>     fpc = fpc, nest = nest, check.strata = check.strata, weights = weights,  #>     data = d, pps = pps, calibrate.formula = calibrate.formula,  #>     ...)  event_times <- data_with_miss$stime[data_with_miss$status == 1] cuts <- quantile(event_times, probs = c(0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8), na.rm = TRUE)  impdata_long_split <- survSplit(Surv(stime, status) ~ .,                                 data = impdata_long,                                 cut = cuts,                                 episode = "tgroup",                                 id = "split_id")  allImputations_split <- imputationList(split(impdata_long_split, impdata_long_split$.imp))  design_split <- svydesign(   strata = ~strata,   id = ~psu,   weights = ~survey_weight,   data = allImputations_split,   nest = TRUE )  my_ph_plot <- svycoxph_CE_mi(   formula_rhs = my_formula,   design_split = design_split,   var_to_test = "caff_binYes",   tgroup_var = "tgroup",   time_var = "stime",   status_var = "status",   main_model_fit = main_fit_pooled,   print_split_summary = TRUE,   show_null_effect = TRUE ) #> [1] "--- Tidy previous_headings: 2. Ad hoc solutions for testing Proportional Hazards
title: Survival Analysis with svyTable1
text: output three key parts: “Main Model” table, “Time-Interval” table, plot. Main (Constant Effect) Model: standard, un-split model. assumes effect asthma constant time. Time-Interval Model & Plot: diagnostic test. check plot see assumption first model valid. plot shows pooled log-Hazard Ratio (coefficient) variable intest across 5 time intervals. perfectly flat, vertical 95% confidence intervals substantially overlap . conclude constant effect (parallel proportional hazards) assumption reasonable. Hence, instead time-split model (2nd output), just report Main (Constant Effect) Model (first output).

title: Formatting Multiple Imputation Results
text: Beyond survey data, common analytical challenge presenting results models fitted multiply imputed datasets. svyTable1 package provides svypooled() function address . takes pooled model object (mipo) mice produces publication-ready regression tables. key feature svypooled() ability create fallacy-safe table. approach displays results primary exposure listing adjustment covariates footnote, preventing misinterpretation covariate p-values.

what: Example: Handling Missing Data in a Survey Design
title: Formatting Multiple Imputation Results
text: following sections illustrate recommended workflow. Data taken NHANES example dataset supplied NHANES package.

previous_headings: Example: Handling Missing Data in a Survey Design
title: Formatting Multiple Imputation Results
text: prepare analytic dataset, define obesity, categorize age, define binary smoking variable, select variables needed imputation survey design.
code: library(svyTable1) library(mice) library(dplyr) library(survey) library(NHANES) library(knitr) library(mitools) data(NHANESraw, package = "NHANES") nhanes_analytic <- NHANESraw %>%   filter(Age >= 20 & WTMEC2YR > 0) %>%    mutate(     Obese = factor(ifelse(BMI >= 30, "Yes", "No"), levels = c("No", "Yes")),     AgeCat = cut(Age, breaks = c(19, 39, 59, 80), labels = c("20-39", "40-59", "60-80")),     Smoke100 = factor(Smoke100, levels = c("No", "Yes"))   ) %>%   select(Obese, AgeCat, Smoke100, Education, SDMVPSU, SDMVSTRA, WTMEC2YR)

title: Formatting Multiple Imputation Results
text: run mice(), fit survey-weighted logistic regression model imputed dataset using svyglm(), combine results using pool(). pooled model object accepted directly svypooled().
code: imputed_data <- mice(nhanes_analytic, m = 2, maxit = 2, seed = 123, printFlag = FALSE)  fit_list <- list() for (i in 1:imputed_data$m) {   completed_data <- complete(imputed_data, i)   design_i <- svydesign(     id = ~SDMVPSU,     strata = ~SDMVSTRA,     weights = ~WTMEC2YR,     nest = TRUE,     data = completed_data   )   fit_list[[i]] <- svyglm(     Obese ~ Smoke100 + AgeCat + Education,     design = design_i,     family = quasibinomial()   ) }  pooled_results <- pool(fit_list)

title: Formatting Multiple Imputation Results
text: recommended format (Westreich Greenland 2013). presents results main exposure lists adjustment variables single footnote. Adjusted Odds Obesity (Fallacy-Safe)
code: svypooled(  pooled_model = pooled_results,  main_exposure = "Smoke100",  adj_var_names = c("AgeCat", "Education"),  measure = "OR",  title = "Adjusted Odds of Obesity (Fallacy-Safe)" )

title: Formatting Multiple Imputation Results
text: version displays results every variable model. useful supplemental materials internal reporting used primary interpretation. Adjusted Odds Obesity (Full Table Appendix)
code: svypooled(  pooled_model = pooled_results,  main_exposure = "Smoke100",  adj_var_names = c("AgeCat", "Education"),  measure = "OR",  title = "Adjusted Odds of Obesity (Full Table for Appendix)",  fallacy_safe = FALSE )

what: Create Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics and Diagnostic Tables
title: Create Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics and Diagnostic Tables
text: svyTable1 R package creating publication-ready tables visualizations complex survey epidemiologic analyses. streamlines creation descriptive “Table 1” summaries, supports multiply imputed regression models, provides diagnostic goodness--fit tools, enables interaction effect reporting, supports survey-weighted survival analysis.

title: Create Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics and Diagnostic Tables
text: Survey Design Integration: Built svydesign objects survey package. Automatic Missing Data Handling: Automatically reports missing values variable. Best Practice Reporting: Defaults “mixed mode” unweighted Ns weighted estimates. Reliability Checks: Implements NCHS Data Presentation Standards Proportions. Flexible Output Modes: "mixed", "weighted", "unweighted". Survival Plotting: svykmplot() publication-ready survey-weighted Kaplan Meier plots number risk. Regression Diagnostics: svydiag() evaluate coefficient reliability. Goodness--Fit: svygof() perform Archer-Lemeshow GOF tests survey logistic regression. Design-Correct AUC: svyAUC() valid AUC estimation complex survey designs. Multiple Imputation Support: svypooled() generates fallacy-safe pooled regression tables mice. Joint effects: jointeffects Simple effects: inteffects Additive interaction: addint, addintlist Survey Cox Regression Contrast Estimation:svycoxph_CE() produces hazard ratio contrasts groups combinations. MI-Compatible Cox Regression Contrasts:svycoxph_CE_mi() extends multiply imputed datasets. Plotting Interaction Effects:plotint() generates publication-ready plots interaction effects estimated addint, jointeffects, inteffects. Automated Interaction Reporting:reportint() creates narrative-ready summaries interaction effects, RERI, AP, joint effects.

title: Create Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics and Diagnostic Tables
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("ehsanx/svyTable1", build_vignettes = TRUE, dependencies = TRUE)

title: Create Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics and Diagnostic Tables
text: key examples. See vignettes complete coverage.

title: Create Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics and Diagnostic Tables
code: library(svyTable1) library(survey) library(dplyr)  data(NHANESraw)  analytic <- NHANESraw %>%   filter(Age >= 20) %>%   mutate(     Obese = factor(ifelse(BMI >= 30, "Yes", "No")),     Hypertension = factor(ifelse(BPSysAve >= 130, "Yes", "No"))   ) %>%   drop_na(Age, Race1, Obese, Hypertension, SDMVPSU, SDMVSTRA, WTMEC2YR)  design <- svydesign(   id = ~SDMVPSU, strata = ~SDMVSTRA, weights = ~WTMEC2YR,   nest = TRUE, data = analytic )  model_int <- svyglm(   Hypertension ~ Obese * Race1 + Age,   design = design,   family = quasibinomial() )  reportint(model_int, factor1_name = "Obese", factor2_name = "Race1")

what: Example: Plotting Interaction Effects with plotint()
title: Create Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics and Diagnostic Tables
code: interaction_results <- addint(   model = model_int,   factor1_name = "Obese",   factor2_name = "Race1",   measures = "all" )  plotint(interaction_results, measure = "RERI")

what: Example: Survey Cox Regression with Contrast Estimation
title: Create Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics and Diagnostic Tables
code: library(survival)  cox_model <- svycoxph(   Surv(followup_time, death) ~ Obese + Age + Race1,   design = design )  svycoxph_CE(   model = cox_model,   contrast_var = "Obese",   ref = "No",   target = "Yes" )

what: Example: Cox Contrasts with Multiple Imputation
title: Create Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics and Diagnostic Tables
code: library(mice)  imp <- mice(analytic, m = 5, seed = 123, printFlag = FALSE)  fit_list <- with(imp, {   d <- svydesign(id = ~SDMVPSU, strata = ~SDMVSTRA, weights = ~WTMEC2YR,                  nest = TRUE, data = complete(data))   svycoxph(Surv(followup_time, death) ~ Obese + Age + Race1, design = d) })  svycoxph_CE_mi(fit_list, contrast_var = "Obese", ref = "No", target = "Yes")

title: Create Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics and Diagnostic Tables
code: addintlist(   model = model_int,   factor1_name = "Obese",   factor2_name = "Race1",   measures = "all" )

what: Calculate Additive Interaction Measures (RERI, AP, S) — addint
title: Calculate Additive Interaction Measures (RERI, AP, S) — addint
text: Calculates measures additive interaction (Relative Excess Risk due Interaction - RERI, Attributable Proportion due interaction - AP, Synergy Index - S) delta method confidence intervals. can use coefficients either joint variable model interaction term model (`svycoxph`, `svyglm`, `coxph`, `glm`). correctly handles variance-covariance matrix survey design objects.

title: Calculate Additive Interaction Measures (RERI, AP, S) — addint
code: addint(   model,   type = c("joint", "interaction"),   coef_names,   measures = "all",   conf.level = 0.95 )

title: Calculate Additive Interaction Measures (RERI, AP, S) — addint
text: model fitted model object (e.g., `svycoxph`, `svyglm`). type Character string: `"joint"` using combined categorical variable, `"interaction"` using main effects product term. coef_names list containing exact names coefficients required calculation, based model `type`: `type = "joint"`: `list(exp1_level = "coef_name_A_only", exp2_level = "coef_name_B_only", both_levels = "coef_name_A_and_B")` `type = "interaction"`: `list(exp1_coef = "coef_name_mainA", exp2_coef = "coef_name_mainB", inter_coef = "coef_name_A_x_B")` Coefficient names must match `names(coef(model))` exactly. measures character vector specifying measures calculate. Options: `"RERI"`, `"AP"`, `"S"`, `""`. Default `""`. conf.level Confidence level interval (default 0.95).

title: Calculate Additive Interaction Measures (RERI, AP, S) — addint
text: list containing named vectors requested measure.   vector includes Estimate, SE (SE RERI AP, SE_log S),   LowerCI, UpperCI. Returns `NULL` partial list `NA` values   calculation fails (e.g., missing coefficients, delta method error).

title: Calculate Additive Interaction Measures (RERI, AP, S) — addint
text: function extracts coefficients variance-covariance matrix fitted model. Based `type` specified ('joint' 'interaction'), selects appropriate coefficients corresponding exposure levels provided `coef_names`. uses delta method via `msm::deltamethod` function calculate standard errors RERI, AP, log(S), constructs confidence intervals. RERI = RR11 - RR10 - RR01 + 1 (ORs/HRs) AP = RERI / RR11 S = (RR11 - 1) / ((RR10 - 1) + (RR01 - 1)) Confidence intervals S calculated log scale exponentiated.

title: Calculate Additive Interaction Measures (RERI, AP, S) — addint
code: # \donttest{ # --- Load required libraries for the example --- if (requireNamespace("survey", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("NHANES", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("tidyr", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("msm", quietly = TRUE)) {    library(survey)   library(NHANES)   library(dplyr)   library(tidyr)   library(msm)    # --- 1. Data Preparation (NHANES Example) ---   data(NHANESraw)    vars_needed <- c("Age", "Race1", "BPSysAve", "BMI", "ObeseStatus", "Hypertension_130",                    "SDMVPSU", "SDMVSTRA", "WTMEC2YR")    nhanes_adults_processed <- NHANESraw %>%     filter(Age >= 20) %>%     mutate(       ObeseStatus = factor(ifelse(BMI >= 30, "Obese", "Not Obese"),                            levels = c("Not Obese", "Obese")),       Hypertension_130 = factor(ifelse(BPSysAve >= 130, "Yes", "No"),                                 levels = c("No", "Yes")),       Race1 = relevel(as.factor(Race1), ref = "White")     ) %>%     select(all_of(vars_needed)) %>%     drop_na()    adult_design_binary <- svydesign(     id = ~SDMVPSU, strata = ~SDMVSTRA, weights = ~WTMEC2YR,     nest = TRUE, data = nhanes_adults_processed   )    # --- 2a. Fit Joint Variable Model ---   adult_design_binary <- update(adult_design_binary,     Race1_ObeseStatus = interaction(Race1, ObeseStatus, sep = "_", drop = TRUE)   )   adult_design_binary <- update(adult_design_binary,     Race1_ObeseStatus = relevel(Race1_ObeseStatus, ref = "White_Not Obese")   )    joint_model_logit <- svyglm(     Hypertension_130 ~ Race1_ObeseStatus + Age,     design = adult_design_binary, family = quasibinomial()   )    # --- 2b. Fit Interaction Term Model ---   interaction_model_logit <- svyglm(     Hypertension_130 ~ Race1 * ObeseStatus + Age,     design = adult_design_binary, family = quasibinomial()   )    # --- 3. Calculate Additive Interaction (Black vs White * Obese vs Not Obese) ---    # --- Using the Joint Model ---   joint_coef_names_black_obese <- list(     exp1_level = "Race1_ObeseStatusBlack_Not Obese", # A=1, B=0     exp2_level = "Race1_ObeseStatusWhite_Obese",    # A=0, B=1     both_levels = "Race1_ObeseStatusBlack_Obese"     # A=1, B=1   )    results_joint <- addint(     model = joint_model_logit,     type = "joint",     coef_names = joint_coef_names_black_obese,     measures = "all"   )   print("--- Results from Joint Model (Black vs Obese Interaction) ---")   print(results_joint)    # --- Using the Interaction Model ---   interaction_coef_names_black_obese <- list(     exp1_coef = "Race1Black",           # Main effect A     exp2_coef = "ObeseStatusObese",     # Main effect B     inter_coef = "Race1Black:ObeseStatusObese" # Interaction A:B   )    results_interact <- addint(     model = interaction_model_logit,     type = "interaction",     coef_names = interaction_coef_names_black_obese,     measures = "all"   )   print("--- Results from Interaction Model (Black vs Obese Interaction) ---")   print(results_interact)  } else {   print("Required packages (survey, NHANES, dplyr, tidyr, msm) not found.") } #> Loading required package: grid #> Loading required package: Matrix #> Loading required package: survival #>  #> Attaching package: 'survey' #> The following object is masked from 'package:graphics': #>  #>     dotchart #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union #>  #> Attaching package: 'tidyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:Matrix': #>  #>     expand, pack, unpack #> [1] "--- Results from Joint Model (Black vs Obese Interaction) ---" #> $RERI #> RERI_Estimate       RERI_SE RERI_CI95_low RERI_CI95_upp  #>    0.02486171    0.31237142   -0.58737502    0.63709844  #>  #> $AP #>  AP_Estimate        AP_SE  AP_CI95_low  AP_CI95_upp  #>  0.009809106  0.122477110 -0.230241619  0.249859830  #>  #> $S #> S_Estimate   S_SE_log S_CI95_low S_CI95_upp  #>  1.0164681  0.2047878  0.6804215  1.5184814  #>  #> [1] "--- Results from Interaction Model (Black vs Obese Interaction) ---" #> $RERI #> RERI_Estimate       RERI_SE RERI_CI95_low RERI_CI95_upp  #>    0.02486171    0.31237142   -0.58737502    0.63709844  #>  #> $AP #>  AP_Estimate        AP_SE  AP_CI95_low  AP_CI95_upp  #>  0.009809106  0.122477110 -0.230241619  0.249859830  #>  #> $S #> S_Estimate   S_SE_log S_CI95_low S_CI95_upp  #>  1.0164681  0.2047878  0.6804215  1.5184814  #>  # }

what: Calculate All Additive Interaction Measures from an Interaction Model — addintlist
title: Calculate All Additive Interaction Measures from an Interaction Model — addintlist
text: Automatically identifies interaction terms fitted model involving two categorical factors (e.g., `~ * B`) calculates measures additive interaction (RERI, AP, S) combination non-reference levels. function requires `addint()` function available.

title: Calculate All Additive Interaction Measures from an Interaction Model — addintlist
code: addintlist(   model,   factor1_name,   factor2_name,   measures = "all",   conf.level = 0.95,   digits = 3 )

title: Calculate All Additive Interaction Measures from an Interaction Model — addintlist
text: model fitted model object (e.g., `svycoxph`, `svyglm`) type `"interaction"` (containing `factor1 * factor2` term). factor1_name Character string: name first factor variable interaction (e.g., `"Race1"`). factor2_name Character string: name second factor variable (e.g., `"ObeseStatus"`). measures character vector specifying measures calculate via `addint()`. Options: `"RERI"`, `"AP"`, `"S"`, `""`. Default `""`. conf.level Confidence level interval (default 0.95). digits Integer. Number decimal places rounding estimates CIs final table. Default 3. (Set NULL rounding).

title: Calculate All Additive Interaction Measures from an Interaction Model — addintlist
text: `tibble` (data frame) summarizing additive interaction results.   Columns include: `Factor1`: Name first factor. `Level1`: Non-reference level first factor comparison. `Factor2`: Name second factor. `Level2`: Non-reference level second factor comparison. `Measure`: additive interaction measure calculated ("RERI", "AP", "S"). `Estimate`: Point estimate measure. `SE`: Standard Error (Note: S, SE log(S)). `CI_low`: Lower confidence interval bound. `CI_upp`: Upper confidence interval bound. Returns empty tibble errors occur.

title: Calculate All Additive Interaction Measures from an Interaction Model — addintlist
text: function serves wrapper around `addint()`. determines levels two specified factors model object, constructs expected coefficient names main effects interaction terms (checking `:B` `B:` formats), calls `addint()` `type = "interaction"` valid combination found model. results compiled single summary table.

title: Calculate All Additive Interaction Measures from an Interaction Model — addintlist
code: # \donttest{ # --- Load required libraries for the example --- # Ensure the 'addint' function is defined or loaded from the package # source("R/addint.R") # If running interactively before package build  if (requireNamespace("survey", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("NHANES", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("tidyr", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("msm", quietly = TRUE)) {    library(survey)   library(NHANES)   library(dplyr)   library(tidyr)   library(msm)    # --- 1. Data Preparation (NHANES Example) ---   data(NHANESraw)    vars_needed <- c("Age", "Race1", "BPSysAve", "BMI", "ObeseStatus", "Hypertension_130",                    "SDMVPSU", "SDMVSTRA", "WTMEC2YR")    nhanes_adults_processed <- NHANESraw %>%     filter(Age >= 20) %>%     mutate(       ObeseStatus = factor(ifelse(BMI >= 30, "Obese", "Not Obese"),                            levels = c("Not Obese", "Obese")),       Hypertension_130 = factor(ifelse(BPSysAve >= 130, "Yes", "No"),                                 levels = c("No", "Yes")),       Race1 = relevel(as.factor(Race1), ref = "White")     ) %>%     select(all_of(vars_needed)) %>%     drop_na()    adult_design_binary <- svydesign(     id = ~SDMVPSU, strata = ~SDMVSTRA, weights = ~WTMEC2YR,     nest = TRUE, data = nhanes_adults_processed   )    # --- 2. Fit Interaction Term Model ---   interaction_model_logit <- svyglm(     Hypertension_130 ~ Race1 * ObeseStatus + Age,     design = adult_design_binary, family = quasibinomial()   )    # --- 3. Calculate all additive interactions ---   all_interactions_table <- addintlist(     model = interaction_model_logit,     factor1_name = "Race1",     factor2_name = "ObeseStatus",     measures = "all"   )    # Print the results table   print(all_interactions_table, n=50)  } else {   print("Required packages (survey, NHANES, dplyr, tidyr, msm) not found.") } #> Calculating for: Race1_Black_vs_ObeseStatus_Obese #> Calculating for: Race1_Hispanic_vs_ObeseStatus_Obese #> Calculating for: Race1_Mexican_vs_ObeseStatus_Obese #> Calculating for: Race1_Other_vs_ObeseStatus_Obese #> # A tibble: 12 × 9 #>    Factor1 Level1   Factor2     Level2 Measure Estimate    SE CI_low CI_upp #>    <chr>   <chr>    <chr>       <chr>  <chr>      <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> #>  1 Race1   Black    ObeseStatus Obese  RERI       0.025 0.312 -0.587  0.637 #>  2 Race1   Black    ObeseStatus Obese  AP         0.01  0.122 -0.23   0.25  #>  3 Race1   Black    ObeseStatus Obese  S          1.02  0.205  0.68   1.52  #>  4 Race1   Hispanic ObeseStatus Obese  RERI       0.258 0.194 -0.123  0.639 #>  5 Race1   Hispanic ObeseStatus Obese  AP         0.157 0.105 -0.048  0.362 #>  6 Race1   Hispanic ObeseStatus Obese  S          1.67  0.382  0.788  3.52  #>  7 Race1   Mexican  ObeseStatus Obese  RERI       0.36  0.253 -0.136  0.857 #>  8 Race1   Mexican  ObeseStatus Obese  AP         0.187 0.116 -0.041  0.415 #>  9 Race1   Mexican  ObeseStatus Obese  S          1.64  0.348  0.829  3.24  #> 10 Race1   Other    ObeseStatus Obese  RERI      -0.299 0.305 -0.896  0.299 #> 11 Race1   Other    ObeseStatus Obese  AP        -0.259 0.316 -0.878  0.36  #> 12 Race1   Other    ObeseStatus Obese  S          0.337 1.76   0.011 10.6   # }

what: Calculate Simple (Stratum-Specific) Effects from a Joint Variable Model — inteffects
title: Calculate Simple (Stratum-Specific) Effects from a Joint Variable Model — inteffects
text: Replicates output interaction-term model (e.g., simple effects `publish()` `emmeans`) calculating stratum-specific comparisons joint-variable model. Allows output log ratio scale consistent column structure, including scale-appropriate standard errors.

title: Calculate Simple (Stratum-Specific) Effects from a Joint Variable Model — inteffects
code: inteffects(   joint_model,   joint_var_name,   factor1_name,   factor2_name,   factor1_levels,   factor2_levels,   level_separator = ".",   scale = c("ratio", "log"),   digits = 2,   conf.level = 0.95 )

title: Calculate Simple (Stratum-Specific) Effects from a Joint Variable Model — inteffects
text: joint_model fitted model object (e.g., `svycoxph`, `svyglm`) used combined joint variable (e.g., `~ A_B`). joint_var_name Character string. name joint variable used model formula (e.g., `"Race1_ObeseStatus"`). factor1_name Character string. name *first* logical factor used create joint variable (e.g., `"Race1"`). Used naming output rows. factor2_name Character string. name *second* logical factor used create joint variable (e.g., `"ObeseStatus"`). Used naming output rows. factor1_levels Character vector. levels *first* logical factor, reference level *first*. factor2_levels Character vector. levels *second* logical factor, reference level *first*. level_separator Character string. separator used create joint level names (e.g., `"_"` `"."`). Default `"."` (R default `interaction()`). scale Character string. scale output estimates, CIs, SE. Options `"ratio"` (default, e.g., /HR) `"log"` (log-/log-HR). digits Integer. Number decimal places rounding estimates, SE, CIs `scale = "ratio"`. Default 2. (Set NULL rounding). conf.level Confidence level interval (default 0.95).

title: Calculate Simple (Stratum-Specific) Effects from a Joint Variable Model — inteffects
text: `tibble` (data frame) columns: `Comparison`: description simple effect, styled similarly     `Publish` package (e.g., "ObeseStatus(Obese vs Obese): Race1(White)"). `Estimate`: point estimate specified `scale`. `SE`: standard error specified `scale`. Calculated using     delta method `scale = "ratio"`. `CI.low`: lower bound confidence interval (specified `scale`). `CI.upp`: upper bound confidence interval (specified `scale`). `p_value`: p-value simple effect (tests H0: logEstimate=0 Estimate=1).

title: Calculate Simple (Stratum-Specific) Effects from a Joint Variable Model — inteffects
code: # \donttest{ # --- Load required libraries for the example --- if (requireNamespace("survey", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("NHANES", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("tidyr", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("msm", quietly = TRUE)) { # msm needed for SE calculation    library(survey)   library(NHANES)   library(dplyr)   library(tidyr)   library(msm) # Load msm    # --- 1. Data Preparation (NHANES Example) ---   data(NHANESraw)    vars_needed <- c("Age", "Race1", "BPSysAve", "BMI", "ObeseStatus", "Hypertension_130",                    "SDMVPSU", "SDMVSTRA", "WTMEC2YR")    nhanes_adults_processed <- NHANESraw %>%     filter(Age >= 20) %>%     mutate(       ObeseStatus = factor(ifelse(BMI >= 30, "Obese", "Not Obese"),                            levels = c("Not Obese", "Obese")),       Hypertension_130 = factor(ifelse(BPSysAve >= 130, "Yes", "No"),                                 levels = c("No", "Yes")),       Race1 = relevel(as.factor(Race1), ref = "White")     ) %>%     select(all_of(vars_needed)) %>%     drop_na()    adult_design_binary <- svydesign(     id = ~SDMVPSU, strata = ~SDMVSTRA, weights = ~WTMEC2YR,     nest = TRUE, data = nhanes_adults_processed   )    # --- 2. Create Joint Variable and Fit Joint Model ---   adult_design_binary <- update(adult_design_binary,     Race1_ObeseStatus = interaction(Race1, ObeseStatus, sep = "_", drop = TRUE)   )   adult_design_binary <- update(adult_design_binary,     Race1_ObeseStatus = relevel(Race1_ObeseStatus, ref = "White_Not Obese")   )    joint_model_logit <- svyglm(     Hypertension_130 ~ Race1_ObeseStatus + Age,     design = adult_design_binary, family = quasibinomial()   )    # --- 3. Run the function ---   f1_levels <- levels(adult_design_binary$variables$Race1)   f2_levels <- levels(adult_design_binary$variables$ObeseStatus)    # --- Example 1: Output on Ratio scale ---   simple_effects_ratio <- inteffects(     joint_model = joint_model_logit,     joint_var_name = "Race1_ObeseStatus",     factor1_name = "Race1",     factor2_name = "ObeseStatus",     factor1_levels = f1_levels,     factor2_levels = f2_levels,     level_separator = "_",     scale = "ratio"   )   print("--- Output on Ratio Scale ---")   print(simple_effects_ratio, n = 50)    # --- Example 2: Output on Log scale ---   simple_effects_log <- inteffects(     joint_model = joint_model_logit,     joint_var_name = "Race1_ObeseStatus",     factor1_name = "Race1",     factor2_name = "ObeseStatus",     factor1_levels = f1_levels,     factor2_levels = f2_levels,     level_separator = "_",     scale = "log"   )   print("--- Output on Log Scale ---")   print(simple_effects_log, n = 50) } #> [1] "--- Output on Ratio Scale ---" #> # what: Calculate Joint Effects from an Interaction Model — jointeffects
title: Calculate Joint Effects from an Interaction Model — jointeffects
text: Calculates joint effect every combination two interacting categorical variables, relative model's reference group. function reproduces output joint-variable model (e.g., `~ A_B`) using results interaction-term model (e.g., `~ * B`). Output can specified log scale (e.g., log-/log-HR) ratio scale (e.g., /HR). works various model types, including `svyglm`, `svycoxph`, `glm`, `coxph`, dynamically identifying main effect interaction coefficients.

title: Calculate Joint Effects from an Interaction Model — jointeffects
code: jointeffects(   interaction_model,   factor1_name,   factor2_name,   scale = c("ratio", "log"),   conf.level = 0.95,   digits = 2 )

title: Calculate Joint Effects from an Interaction Model — jointeffects
text: interaction_model fitted model object (e.g., `svycoxph`, `svyglm`) containing two-way interaction term (e.g., `*B`). factor1_name Character string. name first factor variable interaction (e.g., `"Race1"`). factor2_name Character string. name second factor variable (e.g., `"ObeseStatus"`). scale Character string. scale output estimates, CIs, SE. Options `"ratio"` (default, e.g., /HR) `"log"` (log-/log-HR). conf.level Confidence level interval (default 0.95). digits Integer. Number decimal places rounding estimates, SE, CIs `scale = "ratio"`. Default 2. (Set NULL rounding).

title: Calculate Joint Effects from an Interaction Model — jointeffects
text: `tibble` (data frame) one row combination factor levels. Columns include: `Level1`: level first factor. `Level2`: level second factor. `Estimate`: point estimate specified `scale`. `SE`: standard error specified `scale`. Calculated using     delta method `scale = "ratio"`. `CI.low`: lower bound confidence interval (specified `scale`). `CI.upp`: upper bound confidence interval (specified `scale`).

title: Calculate Joint Effects from an Interaction Model — jointeffects
code: # \donttest{ # --- Load required libraries for the example --- if (requireNamespace("survey", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("NHANES", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("tidyr", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("msm", quietly = TRUE)) { # msm needed for ratio SE    library(survey)   library(NHANES)   library(dplyr)   library(tidyr)   library(msm) # Load msm    # --- 1. Data Preparation (NHANES Example) ---   data(NHANESraw)    vars_needed <- c("Age", "Race1", "BPSysAve", "BMI", "ObeseStatus", "Hypertension_130",                    "SDMVPSU", "SDMVSTRA", "WTMEC2YR")    nhanes_adults_processed <- NHANESraw %>%     filter(Age >= 20) %>%     mutate(       ObeseStatus = factor(ifelse(BMI >= 30, "Obese", "Not Obese"),                            levels = c("Not Obese", "Obese")),       Hypertension_130 = factor(ifelse(BPSysAve >= 130, "Yes", "No"),                                 levels = c("No", "Yes")),       Race1 = relevel(as.factor(Race1), ref = "White")     ) %>%     select(all_of(vars_needed)) %>%     drop_na()    adult_design_binary <- svydesign(     id = ~SDMVPSU, strata = ~SDMVSTRA, weights = ~WTMEC2YR,     nest = TRUE, data = nhanes_adults_processed   )    # --- 2. Fit the Interaction Model ---   interaction_model_logit <- svyglm(     Hypertension_130 ~ Race1 * ObeseStatus + Age,     design = adult_design_binary, family = quasibinomial()   )    # --- 3. Run the function ---    # Example 1: Output on Ratio scale (default)   joint_effects_ratio <- jointeffects(     interaction_model = interaction_model_logit,     factor1_name = "Race1",     factor2_name = "ObeseStatus",     scale = "ratio"   )   print("--- Joint Effects (Ratio Scale) ---")   print(joint_effects_ratio, n = 50)    # Example 2: Output on Log scale   joint_effects_log <- jointeffects(     interaction_model = interaction_model_logit,     factor1_name = "Race1",     factor2_name = "ObeseStatus",     scale = "log"   )   print("--- Joint Effects (Log Scale) ---")   print(joint_effects_log, n = 50) } #> [1] "--- Joint Effects (Ratio Scale) ---" #> # what: Create a Multi-Panel Interaction Report — reportint
title: Create a Multi-Panel Interaction Report — reportint
text: wrapper function automates creation three-panel interaction report (Joint Effects, Simple Effects, Additive Interaction). can return data list, render RStudio Viewer, save source .Rmd file. takes **single pre-fitted model** input works `glm`, `svyglm`, `coxph`, `svycoxph` objects.

title: Create a Multi-Panel Interaction Report — reportint
code: reportint(   interaction_model,   factor1_name = NULL,   factor2_name = NULL,   output = c("list", "viewer", "rmd"),   output_file = NULL,   digits_ratio = 2,   digits_additive = 3,   conf.level = 0.95,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Create a Multi-Panel Interaction Report — reportint
text: interaction_model fitted model object containing interaction term (e.g., `outcome ~ factor1 * factor2 + ...`). factor1_name Character string. name first factor variable. `NULL` (default), function attempt auto-detect interaction terms. factor2_name Character string. name second factor variable. `NULL` (default), function attempt auto-detect interaction terms. output Character string. desired output type: `"list"` (default): Returns named list containing data frames     Panel , B, C, notes Panel D. `"viewer"`: Renders HTML report RStudio     Viewer (default browser). `"rmd"`: Saves auto-generated .Rmd file. Requires     `output_file` set. output_file Character string. file path save .Rmd file (e.g., "my_report.Rmd"). used `output = "rmd"`. digits_ratio Integer. Digits rounding ORs/CIs Panels & B. digits_additive Integer. Digits rounding RERI/AP/S Panel C. conf.level Confidence level (default 0.95). verbose Logical. `TRUE`, prints status messages console.

title: Create a Multi-Panel Interaction Report — reportint
text: `output = "list"`, returns named list data frames. list contains: `joint_effects`, `stratum_specific_effects`, `additive_interaction`, `multiplicative_scale`, `model_details`, two publication-ready summary tables: `effect_modification_report` `Interaction_report`.

title: Create a Multi-Panel Interaction Report — reportint
text: function requires 'svyTable1' 'Publish' packages.

title: Create a Multi-Panel Interaction Report — reportint
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # --- Load required libraries for the example --- if (requireNamespace("svyTable1", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("Publish", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("survey", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("NHANES", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("tidyr", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("broom", quietly = TRUE)) {    library(svyTable1)   library(Publish)   library(survey)   library(NHANES)   library(dplyr)   library(tidyr)   library(broom)    # --- 1. Data Preparation (NHANES Example) ---   data(NHANESraw)    vars_needed <- c("Age", "Race1", "BPSysAve", "BMI", "ObeseStatus", "Hypertension_130",                    "SDMVPSU", "SDMVSTRA", "WTMEC2YR")    nhanes_adults_processed <- NHANESraw %>%     dplyr::filter(Age >= 20) %>%     dplyr::mutate(       ObeseStatus = factor(ifelse(BMI >= 30, "Obese", "Not Obese"),                            levels = c("Not Obese", "Obese")),       Hypertension_130 = factor(ifelse(BPSysAve >= 130, "Yes", "No"),                                   levels = c("No", "Yes")),       Race1 = relevel(as.factor(Race1), ref = "White")     ) %>%     dplyr::select(dplyr::all_of(vars_needed)) %>%     tidyr::drop_na()    adult_design_binary <- svydesign(     id = ~SDMVPSU, strata = ~SDMVSTRA, weights = ~WTMEC2YR,     nest = TRUE, data = nhanes_adults_processed   )    # --- 2. FIT ONLY THE INTERACTION MODEL ---    interaction_model_fit <- svyglm(     Hypertension_130 ~ Race1 * ObeseStatus + Age,     design = adult_design_binary, family = quasibinomial()   )    # --- 3. Run the wrapper function ---    report_list <- reportint(     interaction_model = interaction_model_fit   )    # You can then print the individual panel tables:   # print(report_list$joint_effects)   # print(report_list$stratum_specific_effects)    # --- OR ---    # Print the single, publication-ready summary tables:   # print(report_list$effect_modification_report)   # print(report_list$Interaction_report)  } } # }

title: Calculate and Optionally Plot a Design-Correct AUC for a Survey Model — svyAUC
text: `plot = FALSE` (default), returns `data.frame` AUC, SE, 95 `plot = TRUE`, invisibly returns list containing summary `data.frame` another `data.frame` ROC curve coordinates (TPR FPR).

title: Calculate and Optionally Plot a Design-Correct AUC for a Survey Model — svyAUC
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Ensure required packages are loaded if (requireNamespace("survey", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("NHANES", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE)) {    # 1. Prepare Data   data(NHANESraw, package = "NHANES")   nhanes_data <- NHANESraw %>%     dplyr::filter(Age >= 20) %>%     dplyr::mutate(ObeseStatus = factor(ifelse(BMI >= 30, "Obese", "Not Obese"),                                        levels = c("Not Obese", "Obese"))) %>%     dplyr::filter(complete.cases(ObeseStatus, Age, Gender, Race1,                                  WTMEC2YR, SDMVPSU, SDMVSTRA))    # 2. Create a replicate design object   std_design <- survey::svydesign(     ids = ~SDMVPSU,     strata = ~SDMVSTRA,     weights = ~WTMEC2YR,     nest = TRUE,     data = nhanes_data   )   rep_design <- survey::as.svrepdesign(std_design)    # 3. Fit a survey logistic regression model using the replicate design   fit_obesity_rep <- survey::svyglm(     ObeseStatus ~ Age + Gender + Race1,     design = rep_design,     family = quasibinomial()   )    # 4. Calculate the design-correct AUC   auc_results <- svyAUC(fit_obesity_rep, rep_design)   print(auc_results) } } # }

what: Test Constant Effect (PH) Assumption for Survey Cox Models — svycoxph_CE
title: Test Constant Effect (PH) Assumption for Survey Cox Models — svycoxph_CE
text: function provides valid alternative cox.zph() complex survey designs. checks Constant Effect (Proportional Hazards) assumption splitting follow-time intervals (based event quantiles), fitting separate models interval, plotting estimated coefficients time.

title: Test Constant Effect (PH) Assumption for Survey Cox Models — svycoxph_CE
code: svycoxph_CE(   formula_rhs,   design,   var_to_test,   time_var = "stime",   status_var = "status",   n_intervals = 5,   design_ids = NULL,   design_weights = NULL,   design_strata = NULL,   verbose = FALSE,   print_main_model = TRUE,   print_split_summary = TRUE,   add_smoother = FALSE,   title = NULL,   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   use_classic_theme = TRUE,   show_null_effect = TRUE )

title: Test Constant Effect (PH) Assumption for Survey Cox Models — svycoxph_CE
text: formula_rhs string specifying right-hand side Cox model formula (e.g., "treatment + age + sex"). design original, un-split svydesign object. var_to_test string specifying exact coefficient name plot (e.g., "age" "treatmentYes"). time_var string time--event variable name (default "stime"). status_var string event status variable name (default "status", usually 0/1). n_intervals Integer. number time intervals create based event time quantiles (default 5). design_ids (Optional) formula specifying cluster IDs (e.g., ~psu) used automatic extraction fails. design_weights (Optional) formula specifying survey weights (e.g., ~weight) used automatic extraction fails. design_strata (Optional) formula specifying strata (e.g., ~strata) used automatic extraction fails. verbose Logical. TRUE, prints debugging information cut-points convergence. print_main_model Logical. TRUE, prints tidy summary main (un-split) model. print_split_summary Logical. TRUE, prints tidy summary table coefficients every time interval. add_smoother Logical. TRUE, adds loess smooth line plot. title String. Custom title plot. xlab String. Custom x-axis label. ylab String. Custom y-axis label. use_classic_theme Logical. TRUE, uses theme_classic(). show_null_effect Logical. TRUE, draws dashed red line y=0.

title: Test Constant Effect (PH) Assumption for Survey Cox Models — svycoxph_CE
text: ggplot object showing coefficient trend time.

title: Test Constant Effect (PH) Assumption for Survey Cox Models — svycoxph_CE
text: Methodology: function uses "Event-Based Splitting." Instead splitting time equal chunks (e.g., every 5 years), splits time based quantiles event times (e.g., 20th, 40th percentiles). ensures interval contains roughly number events, maintaining statistical power across segments. Fix Pipe/Subset Errors: Survey design objects created via magrittr pipes subset() often easily reconstructed. function attempts automatically extract necessary design components (ids, weights, strata) attach data splitting. fails, user can manually provide design_ids, design_weights, design_strata arguments.

title: Test Constant Effect (PH) Assumption for Survey Cox Models — svycoxph_CE
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # --- 1. Load data and create a design --- library(survey) library(dplyr) data(nhanes_mortality, package = "svyTable1")  # Create a base design analytic_design <- svydesign(   strata = ~strata,   id = ~psu,   weights = ~survey_weight,   data = nhanes_mortality,   nest = TRUE )  # Prepare data (filter to >0 time) data_clean <- analytic_design$variables %>%   dplyr::filter(stime > 0) %>%   mutate(caff_bin = ifelse(caff == "No consumption", "No", "Yes"))  # Create final design object final_design <- svydesign(   strata = ~strata,   id = ~psu,   weights = ~survey_weight,   data = data_clean,   nest = TRUE )  # --- Example 1: Standard Usage --- svycoxph_CE(   formula_rhs = "caff_bin + age",   design = final_design,   var_to_test = "age",   time_var = "stime",   status_var = "status" )  # --- Example 2: Manual Safety Valve (if automatic extraction fails) --- svycoxph_CE(   formula_rhs = "caff_bin + age",   design = final_design,   var_to_test = "caff_binYes", # Note: Check exact coef name   design_ids = ~psu,   design_weights = ~survey_weight,   design_strata = ~strata ) } # }

what: Test Constant Effect (PH) Assumption for Pooled svycoxph Models — svycoxph_CE_mi
title: Test Constant Effect (PH) Assumption for Pooled svycoxph Models — svycoxph_CE_mi
text: function provides valid alternative cox.zph() complex survey designs multiple imputation. takes multiply-imputed survey design object split time intervals (using survival::survSplit) fits separate pooled model interval. generates plot coefficients time provides tidy summary tables guide model selection.

title: Test Constant Effect (PH) Assumption for Pooled svycoxph Models — svycoxph_CE_mi
code: svycoxph_CE_mi(   formula_rhs,   design_split,   var_to_test,   tgroup_var = "tgroup",   time_var = "followup",   status_var = "death",   main_model_fit = NULL,   print_split_summary = TRUE,   ... )

title: Test Constant Effect (PH) Assumption for Pooled svycoxph Models — svycoxph_CE_mi
text: formula_rhs string RHS Cox model (e.g., "var + age"). design_split svyimputationList object, created data *already split* using survSplit(). var_to_test string exact coefficient name plot (e.g., "active_asthma" "age"). tgroup_var string time-interval variable created survSplit (default "tgroup"). time_var string original 'stop' time variable split data (default "followup" "stime"). status_var string event status variable (default "death" "status"). main_model_fit pooled svycoxph fit object (class mipo). main, un-split model. optional, highly recommended, function print tidy summary . print_split_summary logical. TRUE, prints tidy summary table pooled coefficients interval models. ... arguments passed plotting, title, xlab, ylab, add_smoother (TRUE/FALSE), use_classic_theme (TRUE/FALSE), show_null_effect (TRUE/FALSE).

title: Test Constant Effect (PH) Assumption for Pooled svycoxph Models — svycoxph_CE_mi
text: ggplot object showing coefficient trend time.

title: Test Constant Effect (PH) Assumption for Pooled svycoxph Models — svycoxph_CE_mi
text: Interpret Results: function helps decide model report paper. 1.  Examine "Time-Varying Effect Plot":     * plot flat: confidence intervals time         intervals substantially overlap. indicates effect         variable constant time.     * plot sloped: clear, non-random trend (upward         downward) suggests effect constant. statistical         test check confidence intervals         different time points (e.g., first last) ** overlap. 2.  Choose Final Model:     * assumption MET (plot flat): report         "Tidy Table Final Paper (Constant Effect Assumption Met)".         single, pooled model valid, precise,         correct model report.     * assumption VIOLATED (plot sloped):         must report main model. statistically invalid.         correct model report time-split model,         summarized "Tidy Summary Time-Interval Models"         table.

title: Test Constant Effect (PH) Assumption for Pooled svycoxph Models — svycoxph_CE_mi
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  # --- 1. Load Libraries --- library(svyTable1) library(dplyr) library(survival) library(survey) library(mitools) library(mice) library(ggplot2) library(knitr)  # --- 2. Load data and create base design --- data(nhanes_mortality) analytic_design <- svydesign(   strata = ~strata,   id = ~psu,   weights = ~survey_weight,   data = nhanes_mortality,   nest = TRUE )  # --- 3. Create analysis data.frame and INDUCE MISSINGNESS in COVARIATES --- set.seed(123) data_with_miss <- analytic_design$variables %>%   filter(stime > 0) %>%   mutate(     # Create the exposure variable (complete)     caff_bin = factor(       ifelse(caff == "No consumption", "No", "Yes"),       levels = c("No", "Yes")     ),     # Induce 10% missingness in 'age' (a confounder)     age = ifelse(runif(n()) < 0.10, NA, age),      # Induce 15% MAR missingness in 'bmi_cat' (a confounder)     bmi_cat = factor(ifelse(age > 50 & runif(n()) < 0.15, NA, as.character(bmi.cat)))   )  print("--- Missingness Induced in Covariates ---") print(mice::md.pattern(data_with_miss[, c("age", "bmi_cat", "caff_bin", "stime", "status")],                        plot=FALSE))  # --- 4. Add Nelson-Aalen hazard (auxiliary variable for MICE) --- data_with_miss$nelson_aalen <- nelsonaalen(   data_with_miss,   time = stime,   status = status )  # --- 5. Run MICE --- print("--- Starting MICE ---") M_IMPUTATIONS <- 5 MAX_ITERATIONS <- 5  pred_matrix <- make.predictorMatrix(data_with_miss) vars_to_keep_as_is <- c("id", "survey.weight", "psu", "strata",                         "stime", "status", "nelson_aalen", "caff_bin", "sex") pred_matrix[, vars_to_keep_as_is] <- 0 pred_matrix[vars_to_keep_as_is, ] <- 0  imputed_data <- mice(   data_with_miss,   m = M_IMPUTATIONS,   maxit = MAX_ITERATIONS,   predictorMatrix = pred_matrix,   method = 'pmm',   seed = 123,   printFlag = FALSE ) print("--- MICE Complete ---")  # --- 6. Create Stacked Long-Format Data --- impdata_long <- mice::complete(imputed_data, "long", include = FALSE)  # --- 7. Fit the MAIN (Constant Effect) Model --- print("--- Fitting Main Pooled (Constant Effect) Model ---")  allImputations_main <- imputationList(split(impdata_long, impdata_long$.imp)) design_main <- svydesign(   strata = ~strata,   id = ~psu,   weights = ~survey_weight,   data = allImputations_main,   nest = TRUE )  my_formula <- "caff_bin + sex + age + bmi_cat" main_formula <- as.formula(paste0("Surv(stime, status) ~ ", my_formula))  main_fit_list <- with(design_main, svycoxph(main_formula)) main_fit_pooled <- pool(main_fit_list)  # --- 8. Create the SPLIT-TIME Design --- print("--- Creating Split-Time Design ---") event_times <- data_with_miss$stime[data_with_miss$status == 1] cuts <- quantile(event_times, probs = c(0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8), na.rm = TRUE)  impdata_long_split <- survSplit(Surv(stime, status) ~ .,                                 data = impdata_long,                                 cut = cuts,                                 episode = "tgroup",                                 id = "split_id")  allImputations_split <- imputationList(split(impdata_long_split,                                              impdata_long_split$.imp))  design_split <- svydesign(   strata = ~strata,   id = ~psu,   weights = ~survey_weight,   data = allImputations_split,   nest = TRUE )  # --- 9. Run the PH Test Function and Print the Plot --- print("--- Calling svycoxph_CE_mi function to test 'caff_binYes' ---")  my_ph_plot <- svycoxph_CE_mi(   formula_rhs = my_formula,   design_split = design_split,   var_to_test = "caff_binYes", # Test the exposure   tgroup_var = "tgroup",   time_var = "stime",   status_var = "status",   main_model_fit = main_fit_pooled, # Pass the main model here   print_split_summary = TRUE,   show_null_effect = TRUE )  # Explicitly print the plot print(my_ph_plot)  } # } # End \dontrun{}

what: Perform Reliability Diagnostics on Survey Regression Models — svydiag
title: Perform Reliability Diagnostics on Survey Regression Models — svydiag
text: function takes fitted survey regression model object (e.g., `svyglm` `svycoxph`) produces tibble key reliability diagnostic metrics coefficient.

title: Perform Reliability Diagnostics on Survey Regression Models — svydiag
code: svydiag(fit, p_threshold = 0.05, rse_threshold = 30)

title: Perform Reliability Diagnostics on Survey Regression Models — svydiag
text: fit fitted model object `survey` package, `svyglm` `svycoxph`. p_threshold numeric value (0 1) significance threshold. Defaults `0.05`. rse_threshold numeric value flagging high Relative Standard Error (RSE). Defaults `30`.

title: Perform Reliability Diagnostics on Survey Regression Models — svydiag
text: `tibble` containing following columns: Term: name regression coefficient. Estimate: coefficient's point estimate (e.g., log-odds scale logistic models). SE: standard error estimate. p.value: p-value coefficient. is_significant: logical flag, `TRUE` `p.value` less `p_threshold`. CI_Lower: lower bound 95 CI_Upper: upper bound 95 CI_Width: absolute width confidence interval (`CI_Upper - CI_Lower`). RSE_percent: Relative Standard Error, percentage. is_rse_high: logical flag, `TRUE` `RSE_percent` greater equal `rse_threshold`.

title: Perform Reliability Diagnostics on Survey Regression Models — svydiag
text: output provides comprehensive overview help assess stability precision regression coefficient. metrics include: Standard Error (SE): measure estimate's precision. Smaller better. p-value: probability observing data coefficient zero. Confidence Interval (CI) Width: wide CI indicates greater uncertainty. Relative Standard Error (RSE): Calculated `(SE / |Estimate|) * 100`. Note RSE: included comparative purposes, use RSE evaluate reliability regression coefficients recommended agencies like NCHS/CDC. Coefficients near zero can extremely large RSE even precisely estimated. better rely standard error, p-value, confidence interval width reliability assessment.

title: Perform Reliability Diagnostics on Survey Regression Models — svydiag
code: # Ensure required packages are loaded if (requireNamespace("survey", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("NHANES", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE)) {    # 1. Prepare Data using the NHANES example   data(NHANESraw, package = "NHANES")   nhanes_adults_with_na <- NHANESraw %>%     dplyr::filter(Age >= 20) %>%     dplyr::mutate(       ObeseStatus = factor(ifelse(BMI >= 30, "Obese", "Not Obese"),                            levels = c("Not Obese", "Obese")),       Race1 = factor(Race1)     )    # Create a complete-case design object for the regression model   nhanes_complete <- nhanes_adults_with_na[complete.cases(     nhanes_adults_with_na[, c("ObeseStatus", "Age", "Race1")]   ), ]    adult_design_complete <- survey::svydesign(     id = ~SDMVPSU,     strata = ~SDMVSTRA,     weights = ~WTMEC2YR,     nest = TRUE,     data = nhanes_complete   )    # 2. Fit a survey-weighted logistic regression model   fit <- survey::svyglm(     ObeseStatus ~ Age + Race1,     design = adult_design_complete,     family = quasibinomial()   )    # 3. Get the reliability diagnostics table using the new function   diagnostics_table <- svydiag(fit)    # Print the resulting table   print(diagnostics_table)    # For a publication-ready table, pipe the result to kable()   if (requireNamespace("knitr", quietly = TRUE)) {     knitr::kable(diagnostics_table,                  caption = "Reliability Diagnostics for NHANES Obesity Model",                  digits = 3)   } } #> #
