what: Archer-Lemeshow Goodness-of-Fit Test for Survey Models — svygof
title: Archer-Lemeshow Goodness-of-Fit Test for Survey Models — svygof
text: Performs Archer-Lemeshow goodness--fit (GOF) test logistic regression models fitted complex survey data. test extension Hosmer-Lemeshow test survey designs.

title: Archer-Lemeshow Goodness-of-Fit Test for Survey Models — svygof
code: svygof(fit, design, G = 10)

title: Archer-Lemeshow Goodness-of-Fit Test for Survey Models — svygof
text: implementation formalized function based script discussion R-help mailing list archives: https://stat.ethz.ch/pipermail/r-help/2016-November/443223.html

title: Archer-Lemeshow Goodness-of-Fit Test for Survey Models — svygof
text: fit fitted model object class `svyglm`. design survey design object class `svydesign` `svyrep.design` used fit model. G integer specifying number groups create based fitted probabilities. Defaults 10 (deciles).

title: Archer-Lemeshow Goodness-of-Fit Test for Survey Models — svygof
text: `data.frame` containing F-statistic, numerator (df1) denominator (df2) degrees freedom, p-value test.

title: Archer-Lemeshow Goodness-of-Fit Test for Survey Models — svygof
text: function automates process calculating residuals fitted values, creating groups (deciles default) based fitted probabilities, building new survey design variables, running final Wald test. non-significant p-value (e.g., p > 0.05) suggests evidence poor fit.

title: Archer-Lemeshow Goodness-of-Fit Test for Survey Models — svygof
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Ensure required packages are loaded if (requireNamespace("survey", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("NHANES", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE)) {    # 1. Prepare Data   data(NHANESraw, package = "NHANES")   nhanes_data <- NHANESraw %>%     dplyr::filter(Age >= 20) %>%     dplyr::mutate(ObeseStatus = factor(ifelse(BMI >= 30, "Obese", "Not Obese"),                                        levels = c("Not Obese", "Obese"))) %>%     dplyr::filter(complete.cases(ObeseStatus, Age, Gender, Race1,                                  WTMEC2YR, SDMVPSU, SDMVSTRA))    # 2. Create a replicate design object   std_design <- survey::svydesign(     ids = ~SDMVPSU,     strata = ~SDMVSTRA,     weights = ~WTMEC2YR,     nest = TRUE,     data = nhanes_data   )   rep_design <- survey::as.svrepdesign(std_design)    # 3. Fit a survey logistic regression model using the replicate design   fit_obesity_rep <- survey::svyglm(     ObeseStatus ~ Age + Gender + Race1,     design = rep_design,     family = quasibinomial()   )    # 4. Calculate the design-correct AUC   auc_results <- svyAUC(fit_obesity_rep, rep_design)   print(auc_results) } } # }

what: Create a Survey-Weighted Kaplan-Meier Plot — svykmplot
title: Create a Survey-Weighted Kaplan-Meier Plot — svykmplot
text: function creates publication-ready, survey-weighted Kaplan-Meier plot attached "Number Risk" table censor markings, using `ggplot2` `patchwork`.

title: Create a Survey-Weighted Kaplan-Meier Plot — svykmplot
code: svykmplot(   formula,   design,   time_unit = "years",   time_breaks = seq(0, 16, by = 4),   legend_title = "Strata",   risk_table_title = "Number at Risk",   palette = NULL,   show_pval = TRUE,   show_censor_marks = TRUE,   base_font_size = 11,   table_font_size = 3.5 )

title: Create a Survey-Weighted Kaplan-Meier Plot — svykmplot
text: formula survival formula, e.g., `Surv(stime, status) ~ strata_var`. design survey design object created `survey` package. time_unit unit time x-axis. One `"days"`, `"months"`, `"years"`. determines divisor time variable. time_breaks numeric vector breaks x-axis, e.g., `seq(0, 10, = 2)`. legend_title character string legend title. risk_table_title character string "Number Risk" table's y-axis title. palette character vector color codes (e.g., hex codes) use strata. show_pval Logical. `TRUE`, calculates displays survey-weighted log-rank test p-value. show_censor_marks Logical. `TRUE`, displays censor markings (`+`) survival curves. base_font_size Base font size plot theme. table_font_size Font size text risk table.

title: Create a Survey-Weighted Kaplan-Meier Plot — svykmplot
text: list containing following components: plot final combined `ggplot` object (plot + table) `patchwork`. table `data.frame` (tibble) number--risk data. p_value numeric p-value survey-weighted log-rank test (`show_pval = TRUE`). km_fit `svykm` fit object `survey` package. logrank_test `svylogrank` test object (`show_pval = TRUE`).

title: Create a Survey-Weighted Kaplan-Meier Plot — svykmplot
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # This example uses the 'nhanes_mortality' dataset,  if (requireNamespace("survey", quietly = TRUE)) {    # 1. Load the data   data(nhanes_mortality)    # 2. Create the main survey design object   analytic_design <- survey::svydesign(     strata = ~strata,     id = ~psu,     weights = ~survey_weight,     data = nhanes_mortality,     nest = TRUE   )    # 3. Create a subsetted design for females   design_female <- subset(analytic_design, sex == "Female")    # 4. Define the formula   km_formula <- Surv(stime, status) ~ caff    # 5. Define a 4-color palette   distinct_palette <- c("#377EB8", "#FF7F00", "#4DAF4A", "#E41A1C")    # 6. Run the function   km_results_female <- svykmplot(     formula = km_formula,     design = design_female,     legend_title = "Caffeine Consumption",     time_unit = "days", # Use "days" so divisor is 1     time_breaks = seq(0, 240, by = 60),     palette = distinct_palette,     show_pval = TRUE,     show_censor_marks = TRUE   )    # 7. Display the plot (and correct the x-axis label)   if (requireNamespace("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {     km_results_female$plot +       ggplot2::labs(x = "Follow-up Time (Months)")   }    # 8. Print the at-risk table   print(km_results_female$table)  } } # }

what: Create a Publication-Ready Table for Pooled Model Results — svypooled
title: Create a Publication-Ready Table for Pooled Model Results — svypooled
text: function takes pooled model object `mice` package creates publication-ready HTML table model's effect estimates (e.g., odds ratios, hazard ratios). can produce two types tables: 1.  **"fallacy-safe"** table (`fallacy_safe = TRUE`), displays     results main exposure variable lists adjustment     variables footnote. helps prevent misinterpretation     statistics covariates. 2.  **full table** (`fallacy_safe = FALSE`), displays results     variables model, grouped variable name.

title: Create a Publication-Ready Table for Pooled Model Results — svypooled
code: svypooled(   pooled_model,   main_exposure,   adj_var_names,   measure = "OR",   title = "Adjusted Model Results",   fallacy_safe = TRUE )

title: Create a Publication-Ready Table for Pooled Model Results — svypooled
text: pooled_model `mipo` object resulting `mice::pool()`. contains pooled results analyses multiply imputed datasets. main_exposure character string specifying name main exposure variable model. function uses identify variable's results show "fallacy-safe" mode. adj_var_names character vector names adjustment variables (covariates) included model. measure character string column header effect measure (e.g., "", "HR", "RR"). Defaults "". title character string table's caption. fallacy_safe logical value. `TRUE` (default), function returns table showing main exposure lists covariates footnote. `FALSE`, returns full table model terms.

title: Create a Publication-Ready Table for Pooled Model Results — svypooled
text: HTML table object class `kableExtra`. object can   printed directly R Markdown documents saved.

title: Create a Publication-Ready Table for Pooled Model Results — svypooled
text: function processes `mipo` object (result `mice::pool()`). exponentiates estimates, calculates 95 formats results clean HTML table using `knitr::kable()` `kableExtra`. P-values formatted three decimal places, values less 0.001 shown "<0.001".

title: Create a Publication-Ready Table for Pooled Model Results — svypooled
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Load required packages for the example library(mice) library(dplyr) library(survey) library(NHANES)  # --- 1. Data Preparation --- # We'll prepare a clean analytic dataset from the raw NHANES data. # Note: We convert the outcome 'Obese' to a numeric 0/1 variable for svyglm. data(NHANESraw, package = "NHANES") nhanes_analytic <- NHANESraw %>%   dplyr::filter(Age >= 20 & WTMEC2YR > 0) %>%   mutate(     Obese_numeric = ifelse(BMI >= 30, 1, 0),     AgeCat = cut(Age, breaks = c(19, 39, 59, 80), labels = c("20-39", "40-59", "60-80")),     Smoke100 = factor(Smoke100, levels = c("No", "Yes"))   ) %>%   select(Obese_numeric, AgeCat, Smoke100, Education, SDMVPSU, SDMVSTRA, WTMEC2YR)  # --- 2. Perform Imputation and Pooled Analysis --- # Set survey option to handle lonely PSUs, a common issue with NHANES data. options(survey.lonely.psu = "adjust")  # Impute the analytic dataset imputed_data <- mice(nhanes_analytic, m = 2, maxit = 2, seed = 123, printFlag = FALSE)  # Use with() to run a survey-weighted GLM on each imputed dataset fit_imputed <- with(imputed_data,                     svyglm(Obese_numeric ~ Smoke100 + AgeCat + Education,                            design = svydesign(id = ~SDMVPSU, strata = ~SDMVSTRA,                                               weights = ~WTMEC2YR, nest = TRUE, data = .data),                            family = quasibinomial())                     )  # Pool the results from all models into a single 'mipo' object pooled_results <- pool(fit_imputed)  # --- 3. Generate Tables with svypooled --- # Example A: Create a "fallacy-safe" table (default) svypooled(  pooled_model = pooled_results,  main_exposure = "Smoke100",  adj_var_names = c("AgeCat", "Education"),  measure = "OR",  title = "Adjusted Odds of Obesity (Fallacy-Safe)" )  # Example B: Create a full table with all variables svypooled(  pooled_model = pooled_results,  main_exposure = "Smoke100",  adj_var_names = c("AgeCat", "Education"),  measure = "OR",  title = "Adjusted Odds of Obesity (Full Table for Appendix)",  fallacy_safe = FALSE ) } # }

what: Create a Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics Table — svytable1
title: Create a Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics Table — svytable1
text: Generates "Table 1" descriptive statistics complex survey data, stratified outcome variable. supports different reporting modes, optional comma formatting, optional reliability checks based NCHS Data Presentation Standards.

title: Create a Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics Table — svytable1
code: svytable1(   design,   strata_var,   table_vars,   mode = "mixed",   commas = TRUE,   reliability_checks = FALSE,   return_metrics = FALSE )

title: Create a Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics Table — svytable1
text: design survey design object created survey package. strata_var string name stratification variable. variable contains NA values, automatically grouped separate 'Missing' stratum output table. table_vars character vector variable names summarize. mode string specifying output type: "mixed" (default), "weighted", "unweighted". commas Logical; TRUE (default), large numbers counts formatted commas. reliability_checks Logical; TRUE, performs reliability checks. Unreliable estimates replaced asterisk (*). rules based NCHS guidelines. proportions (categorical variables), estimate suppressed meets following criteria: Unweighted Sample Size < 30: actual number survey participants cell small produce stable estimate. Effective Sample Size < 30: accounting complex survey design, estimate's precision equivalent simple random sample fewer 30 people. Degrees Freedom < 8: variance estimate unstable, making entire estimate unreliable. Confidence Interval Width >= 30%: 95% confidence interval 30 percentage points wide wider, indicating extreme imprecision. Conditional Relative CI Width > 130%: confidence interval width 5% 30%, also checked see excessively large relative estimate . means (numeric variables), estimate suppressed : Relative Standard Error (RSE) >= 30%: standard error 30% mean's value, indicating high imprecision. Defaults FALSE. return_metrics Logical; TRUE `reliability_checks` also TRUE, function returns list containing formatted table detailed data frame reliability metrics. includes RSE specific TRUE/FALSE columns (e.g., `fail_n_30`, `fail_eff_n_30`) suppression rule. Defaults FALSE.

title: Create a Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics Table — svytable1
text: `return_metrics` FALSE (default), returns data.frame. TRUE,   returns list two elements: `formatted_table` `reliability_metrics`.

title: Create a Survey-Weighted Descriptive Statistics Table — svytable1
code: # Ensure required packages are loaded if (requireNamespace("survey", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("NHANES", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE)) {    # 1. Prepare Data using NHANES   data(NHANESraw, package = "NHANES")   nhanes_adults_with_na <- NHANESraw %>%     dplyr::filter(Age >= 20) %>%     dplyr::mutate(       ObeseStatus = factor(ifelse(BMI >= 30, "Obese", "Not Obese"),                            levels = c("Not Obese", "Obese"))     )    adult_design_with_na <- survey::svydesign(     id = ~SDMVPSU,     strata = ~SDMVSTRA,     weights = ~WTMEC2YR,     nest = TRUE,     data = nhanes_adults_with_na   )    # 2. Basic Example: Create a simple Table 1   vars_to_summarize <- c("Age", "Gender", "Race1", "Education")   table1 <- svytable1(     design = adult_design_with_na,     strata_var = "ObeseStatus",     table_vars = vars_to_summarize   )   print(table1)    # 3. Advanced Example: Use reliability checks and get detailed metrics   results <- svytable1(     design = adult_design_with_na,     strata_var = "ObeseStatus",     table_vars = vars_to_summarize,     reliability_checks = TRUE,     return_metrics = TRUE   )    # View the table with unreliable estimates suppressed (*)   print(results$formatted_table)    # View the detailed report card of reliability
